column1: The Winter Park area's first human residents were migrant Muscogee people who had earlier intermingled with the Choctaw and other indigenous people. In a process of ethnogenesis
column2: the Native Americans formed a new culture which they called "Seminole"
column3: a derivative of the Mvskoke' (a Creek language) word simano-li
column4: an adaptation of the Spanish cimarrón which means "wild" (in their case
column5: "wild men")
column6: or "runaway" [men].  The site was first inhabited by Europeans in 1858
column7: when David Mizell Jr. bought an 8-acre (32
column11: called Lake View by the inhabitants
column12: grew up around Mizell's plot. It got a post office and a new name—Osceola—in 1870.

column1: The area did not develop rapidly until 1880
column2: when a South Florida Railroad track connecting Orlando and Sanford was laid a few miles west of Osceola. Shortly afterwards
column3: Loring Chase came to Orange County from Chicago to recuperate from a lung disease. In his travels
column4: he discovered the pretty group of lakes just east of the railbed. He enlisted a wealthy New Englander
column5: Oliver E. Chapman
column6: and they assembled a very large tract of land for $13
column9: upon which they planned the town of Winter Park. Over the next four years they plotted the town
column11: built a town hall and a store
column13: and required all buildings to meet stylistic and architectural standards. They promoted it heavily. During this time
column14: the Winter Park Post Office opened
column15: and the railroad constructed a depot
column16: connected to Osceola by a dirt road.

column2: a group of businessmen started the Winter Park Company and incorporated it with the Florida Legislature; Chase and Chapman sold the town to the new company. In a land bubble characteristic of Florida history
column3: land prices soared from less than $2 per acre to over $200
column4: with at least one sale recorded at $300 per acre.

column2: the Congregational Assembly of Florida started Rollins College
column3: the state's first four-year college. The following year the Seminole Hotel on Lake Osceola opened. This was a resort complete with the luxuries of the day: gas lights
column4: steam heating
column5: a string orchestra

column1: The first president to visit was Chester A. Arthur
column2: who reported that Winter Park was "the prettiest place I have seen in Florida"

column1: President Grover Cleveland visited the area and was given a huge reception at the Seminole Hotel on February 23
column2: 1888. He enjoyed the Bounding Horse Cart ride and stated that it was the most pleasant diversion of his Florida trip. The New York Times reported on his visit that "The Philadelphian and Bostonian founders had done a good job with the town."

column1: The following four years both hotel and the town became a fashionable winter resort for northern visitors. The next president to visit the area was Franklin D. Roosevelt in March 1936. He was conferred an honorary degree in literature at Rollins College.
President Barack Obama visited Rollins College on August 2
column2: 2012 to give a speech that was part of his re-election campaign.

column1: The Winter Park Public Library is located at 460 E. New England Avenue in the heart of Winter Park. Its origins date back to 1885
column2: when nine women organized to create a lending library for their small community
column3: which was still in its infancy at the time. The library has been located at its present site since 1979.

column2: Charles Hosmer Morse became the biggest land owner in Winter Park. His patronage continued in the 1920s

column8: the land is a nature preserve that houses an orange grove and over 30 peacocks. Winter Park locals consider the peacock to be a pet to the entire community. The peacock is on the official Winter Park seal
column9: is featured in a number of official city documents

column4:
wrote a letter to the editor warning Orange County mayors of the sinkhole danger that could be posed by overdevelopment and excessive groundwater use. Swanson predicted that the west Winter Park area would be especially at risk.  In May 1981, during a period of record-low water levels in Florida's limestone aquifer, a massive sinkhole opened near the corner of Denning Drive and Fairbanks Avenue.
The sinkhole first appeared on the evening of May 8, 1981 near the house of Winter Park resident Mae Rose Williams. Within a few hours, a 40-year-old sycamore tree near her house had fallen into the sinkhole. The next morning, the hole expanded to nearly 40 feet (12 m) wide. In a story in the Orlando Sentinel, she said that as the sun rose, she heard a noise like giant beavers chewing" as the hole began to devour more of her land. The hole was collapsing rapidly. By noon
column5: as she realized that her home was slipping into the expanding hole
column6: she and the family evacuated and removed their belongings. That afternoon her house fell into the sinkhole
column7: and within a few hours the house was irrevocably on its way into the sinkhole's center

column1: The hole eventually widened to 320 feet (98 m) and to a depth of 90 feet (27 m). The following fell into the sinkhole: five Porsches at a repair shop
column2: a pickup truck with camper top
column3: the Winter Park municipal pool
column4: and large portions of Denning Drive. By May 9

column1: The sinkhole drew national attention and became a popular tourist attraction during the summer of 1981. A carnival-like atmosphere arose around the area

column1: The city is northeast of and adjacent to Orlando. Elevation ranges between 66 and 97 feet (20 and 30 m) above sea level.
According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.2 square miles (26.3 km2)
column3: of which 8.7 square miles (22.5 km2) is land and 1.5 square miles (3.9 km2) (14.62%) is water. It is nestled among the Winter Park Chain of Lakes
column4: a series of lakes interconnected by a series of navigable canals
column5: which were originally created for flood control and to run logs to a sawmill on present-day Lake Virginia. The lakes are popular for boating

column1: The city is traversed by the old East Florida and Atlantic Railroad ("Dinky Line") railroad bed
column2: which until the 1960s had a stop at Lake Virginia/Rollins College at the city park now known as Dinky Dock. Much of this right of way has been converted to a rail-trail pedestrian/biking path in the form of the Cady Way Trail
column3: which leads from Cady Way Park toward the Baldwin Park neighborhood and downtown Orlando
column4: and in the opposite direction to Oviedo and beyond (via the Florida Trail)
column5: due to a new pedestrian bridge spanning Semoran Boulevard (SR 436) in Orange County.

column1: SunRail operates a rail line through Winter Park on the former Atlantic Coast Line
